user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Input:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Input (struct SHA1Context *context, const unsigned char *message_array,
           unsigned length)
{
  if (! length)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
  }
  if (! context || ! message_array)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->computed)
  {
    context->corrupted = 1;
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  while (length-- && ! context->corrupted)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++]
      = (*message_array & 0xFF);
    context->length_low += 8;
    if (context->length_low == 0)
    {
      context->length_high++;
      if (context->length_high == 0)
      {
        context->corrupted = 1;
      }
    }
    if (context->message_block_index == 64)
    {
      SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    }
    message_array++;
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to memcmp (or other standard string-comparison functions such as strcmp/strncmp) are present in the provided code. The function operates on a byte buffer using an explicit length parameter (unsigned length) and pointer arithmetic; it does not attempt to compare null-terminated strings. Therefore Rule 21.14 (prohibiting use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings) is not applicable to any fragment shown. Note: the call to SHA1ProcessMessageBlock(context) is to an external routine whose implementation is not provided here; if checking the entire codebase, that routine should be inspected separately for uses of memcmp on null-terminated strings, but there are no such uses in the provided fragment.
